{{Infobox International Football Competition | tourney_name = CONCACAF Gold Cup | year = 2011 | other_titles = Copa de Oro de la CONCACAF 2011 ''{{Es icon}}'' | image = 2011-concacaf-gold-cup.PNG | size = 200px | champion = Mexico | count = 9 | second = United States | caption = | city = | country = United States | dates = June 5â25, 2011 | num_teams = 12 | confederations = 1 | venues = 13 | cities = 13 | champion = Mexico | count = 6 | second = United States | third = | fourth = | matches = 25 | goals = 80 | attendance = {{#expr: 80108 + 80108 + 21507 + 21507 + 28209 + 28209 + 46012 + 46012 + 18057 + 18057 + 27731 + 27731 + 62000 + 62000 + 25000 + 25000 + 20109 + 20109 + 78807 + 78807 + 45424 + 45424 + 70627 + 70627 + 93420}} | top_scorer = {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Javier HernÃ¡ndez BalcÃ¡zar|Javier HernÃ¡ndez]]
(7 goals)[http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2382089,00.html Chicharito chosen as Gold Cup MVP] | player = {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Javier HernÃ¡ndez BalcÃ¡zar|Javier HernÃ¡ndez]] | prevseason = [[2009 CONCACAF Gold Cup|2009]] | nextseason = [[2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup|2013]] }} The '''2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup''' was the 11th edition of the [[CONCACAF Gold Cup]] competition and 21th CONCACAF regional championship overall in CONCACAF's fifty years of existence. The [[United States]] was the host nation; with over 93,000 in attendance, the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final|final]] was played at the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] in [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]], [[California]] on June 25, 2011.{{Cite news |title=Rose Bowl to host 2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup final |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE66K4D920100721 |agency=[[Reuters]] |work=Reuters.com |date=Jul 21, 2010 |accessdate=August 12, 2010 |quote=Southern California's Rose Bowl will host CONCACAF's 2011 Gold Cup final next June 25, the confederation announced on Wednesday. | first=Gene | last=Cherry}} As winner of the tournament, Mexico qualified for the [[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup]] in Brazil as the representative from [[CONCACAF]].{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/jun/26/west-ham-pablo-barrera-mexico-gold-cup|title=West Ham's Pablo Barrera scores twice to help Mexico to Gold Cup glory |date=26 June 2011|work=Guardian|accessdate=27 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/26/sports/soccer/in-an-early-2-0-hole-mexico-storms-back-to-win-the-gold-cup.html?_r=1&ref=soccer|title=In an Early 2-0 Hole, Mexico Storms Back to Win the Gold Cup|date=26 June 2011|work=New York Times|accessdate=27 June 2011}} ==Participating nations== {| class="wikitable" |- !|Team !|Qualification !|[[CONCACAF Gold Cup#Cumulative results|Appearance
in the Gold Cup]] !|Previous best performance |- !colspan=4|[[North American Football Union|North American zone]] |- |align=left| {{fb|USA}} |align=center| Host |align=center| 11th |align=center| thirteen venuesâthe same number as the 2009 Gold Cupâwas announced on December 16, 2010.{{cite web |title=Gold Cup to visit new cities, stadiums in 2011 |url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2225472,00.html |work=concacaf.com |publisher=CONCACAF |date=2010-12-16 |accessdate=March 30, 2011}} Each stadium hosted a doubleheader, except the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] which hosted the final. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! colspan=5| Group stage |- ! [[File:2008-1226-Pasadena-008-95thRoseBowl.jpg|150px]] |} ==Squads== {{details|2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup squads}} Each team can register a squad of 23 players. ===Suspension of Mexican players=== It was announced during the tournament on June 9, 2011, that five [[Mexico national football team|Mexican]] players, [[AntÃ´nio Naelson|AntÃ´nio Naelson Sinha]], [[Christian BermÃºdez]], [[Ãdgar DueÃ±as]], [[Francisco Javier RodrÃ­guez]] and [[Guillermo Ochoa]], all tested positive for [[clenbuterol]] prior to the Gold Cup and have therefore been withdrawn from the squad.{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2374171,00.html|title= Mexico suspends five players|publisher=CONCACAF.com|date=06/09/2011}} Mexican officials said they believed the positive tests were caused by eating meat tainted with the drug.{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2374230,00.html|title=Mexican team insists doping was accident|publisher=CONCACAF.com|date=06/10/2011}} CONCACAF General Secretary [[Chuck Blazer]] said a meeting of the confederation's national teams committee, which also serves as the organizing committee of the Gold Cup, was to be convened on June 10 to consider the situation, including possibly allowing Mexico to replace the five players. However, the meeting was postponed to allow for more information to be gathered.{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2374790,00.html|title=Meeting on Mexican suspensions postponed|publisher=CONCACAF.com|date=06/11/2011}} The [[Mexican Football Federation]] said on June 14 that the "B" samples of those five involving players were negative.{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2376467,00.html|title=Mexican "B" samples test negative|date=2011-06-15|work=concacaf.com|accessdate=2011-06-15}} The CONCACAF Gold Cup Organizing Committee announced on June 19 that Mexico would be allowed to replace the suspended players.{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2378800,00.html|title=Gold Cup Organizing Committee authorizes Mexico to replace up to five players|publisher=CONCACAF.com|date=2011-06-20}} ==Draw== The teams learned their path to the regional title when CONCACAF announced the groups and match schedule for the 2011 Gold Cup on concacaf.com Tuesday, March 8 at 12 pm ET. The confederation championship ran from June 5 to 25 in 13 different stadiums across the United States, culminating at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena for the championship final.{{cite web |title=Mexico â El Salvador to highlight Gold Cup opener |url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2310439,00.html |work=concacaf.com |publisher=CONCACAF |date=03/08/2011 |accessdate=March 30, 2011}} ==Group stage== For the first round, or group stage, the twelve teams were divided into three groups of four teams. Each group was a round-robin of six games, where each team played one match against each of the other teams in the same group. Teams were awarded three points for a win, one point for a draw and none for a defeat. The teams finishing first and second in each group, as well as the two best-placed third teams among all groups, qualified for the quarter-finals. If two or more teams are equal on points (including ties among third place teams), the manner in which teams advance to the next round are resolved as follows and in the order indicated:{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/staticFiles/b0/6f/0,,12813~159664,00.pdf|title=Regulations in English: CONCACAF Gold Cup 2011|publisher=CONCACAF.com}} # Greater number of points in matches between the tied teams. # Greater goal difference in matches between the tied teams (if more than two teams finish equal on points). # Greater number of goals scored in matches among the tied teams (if more than two teams finish equal on points). # Greater goal difference in all group matches. # Greater number of goals scored in all group matches. # Drawing of lots. ''All Times are U.S. Eastern Daylight Time ([[Eastern Time Zone|UTCâ4]]) (Local Times in parentheses)'' {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !colspan=2|Key to colors in group tables |- | style="background:#cfc; width:20px;"| |align=left|Teams that advanced to the [[#Knockout stage|quarterfinals]] *Group winners *Group runners-up *[[#Ranking of third-placed teams|Best two third-placed teams among all groups]] |} ===Group A=== {{main|2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Group A}} {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" |- ! style="width:165px;"|Team !width="20"|{{Tooltip|Pld|Played}} !width="20"|{{Tooltip|W|Won}} !width="20"|{{Tooltip|D|Drawn}} !width="20"|{{Tooltip|L|Lost}} !width="20"|{{Tooltip|GF|Goals for}} !width="20"|{{Tooltip|GA|Goals against}} !width="20"|{{Tooltip|GD|Goal difference}} !width="20"|{{Tooltip|Pts|Points}} |- style="background:#cfc;" |align=left|{{fb|MEX}} |3||3||0||0||14||1||+13||'''9''' |- style="background:#cfc;" |align=left|{{fb|CRC}} |3||1||1||1||7||5||+2||'''4''' |- style="background:#cfc;" |align=left|{{fb|SLV}} |3||1||1||1||7||7||0||'''4''' |- |align=left|{{fb|CUB}} |3||0||0||3||1||16||â15||'''0''' |} {{footballbox |date = June 5, 2011 |time = 18:00 (17:00 [[Central Time Zone (North America)|UTCâ5]]) |team1 = {{fb-rt|CRC}} |score = [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Group A#Costa Rica vs Cuba|5 â 0]] |report =[http://concacaf.globalsportsmedia.com/page.php?sport=soccer&language_id=us&page=tournament&view=match&match_id=1091679 Report] |team2 = {{fb|CUB}} |goals1 = [[Marco UreÃ±a|UreÃ±a]] {{goal|7||46}}
